Posts.Content: 2009 initial psa at age 54 was 322 since that Luperon, Casodex, Radiation, Provenge, Zytiga, Oxfigo, Xgeva, Xtandi. Right now on Luperon, Xtandi and Xgeva. Psa now 97.7 Sooo looks like he will do the chemo because there is nothing else offered. I want chemo to give more time but not sure if we want sick time. No surgery turmor was to large. Gleason score 9. Spread to lymph nodes in 2009 and to bones in March 2014. We are still talking, thinking and praying on what to do. Carol
Posts.Title: Hope Changes

Posts.Content: We have been to U of M and saw Dr. Hussian He was our second consult back in 2009. He suggested the same thing our oncologist offered. The radiation treatments was by a U of M radiologist. We also went to U of M in 2014 for Oxfigo treatments. I am looking into a clinical trial at U of M but so far nothing more than what we are doing. U of M is looking into combining some drugs such as Zytiga and Xtandi but the trial is not accepting anyone yet. It has been a great past 5 years for new treatments and our oncologist is great at getting Steve on them, but not many has worked to slow the spreading and growing of his prostate cancer. We also went to John Hopkins cancer center and they gave the same opinion as how to treat. Thanks for the suggestion and we will think and talk about anymore any one can give us. Carol
Posts.Title: Hope Changes

Posts.Content: At first my hope was please keep psa undetectable. Than hope was please keep psa from rising. Than hope was please keep psa from doubling. Currently hope has been please let his psa stable in the 90s. Today hope is please let me keep having hope. Carol--Steves wife
Posts.Title: Hope Changes

Posts.Content: At first my hope was please keep psa undetectable. Than hope was please keep psa from rising. Than hope was please keep psa from doubling. Currently hope has been please let his psa stable in the 90s. Today hope is please let me keep having hope. Carol--Steves wife

Posts.Title: Hope Changes

Posts.Content: Hello Good news Psa went from 99.5 to 59.9. Oncologist was impressed that is went down that much after being on Xtandi for only 30 days. I hope this the start of better numbers. It is a Good Day Steve
Posts.Title: Xtandi is working

Posts.Content: Xtandi is now FDA approved before chemo. We went to oncologist today and two weeks ago Steve was denied Xtandi. But as of yesterday it was approved and he can start it. We hope it buys more time before he has to start chemo. Good News !!!
Posts.Title: Xtandi

Posts.Content: Just got back from CTCA in Ilnosis. They were very professional with a caring one on one feeling that I have not felt from our onocolgist. The cancer has advanced and is now extensive liver cancer plus his many bone cancer. They offered Carboplatin which only has a 20 % change of slowing down the growth of cancer in the liver but it was more than our home oncologist offered. The part that is great and is going to help the most is the making some one feel better while they are going through all of this. The help for all the side effects and the symptoms from the cancer that they addressed was very helpful. It made sense to me to make a person feel better will make them tolerate and have success with the treatments. So many times I have been told there is nothing that can be done and now I hear try this--if it does not work call me and I have more ideas. Such as the bad taste in the mouth which makes you not want to eat which leads to nutrition problems- they suggested Zinc 30 mg 1 two times a day and the next day the bad taste was less. He told them the nausea was bad and had to take Zofran --they added Ginger Max and it works. They addressed his blood cell counts and immune system and bone marrow function and vit deficiencies. Maybe they did not offer any more help for the cancer growing than anyone else but the way they work with a person to make they feel better and want to get up and live was wonderful. I hope everyone can find a cancer center who will work at keeping the patient living with Pca and not just surviving with treatments. Carol
Posts.Title: CTCA notes

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, this my first post and I want your opinion. When would you start chemo? My new psa 74, 2009 intial was 311. In april first bone mets showed up 5 ribs. This week test show 6 new in vertibrat and one in pelvis. I have tried everything and cancer is still progessing. I feel fine. I work every day with out pain. My oncologist says start chemo, but I am thinking should I wait till I feel bad or start chemo now and suffer all the effects of chemo now. Would you start chemo when you feel good? Keep on "living with Pca"
Posts.Title: Should I start chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, this my first post and I want your opinion. When would you start chemo? My new psa 74, 2009 intial was 311. In april first bone mets showed up 5 ribs. This week test show 6 new in vertibrat and one in pelvis. I have tried everything and cancer is still progessing. I feel fine. I work every day with out pain. My oncologist says start chemo, but I am thinking should I wait till I feel bad or start chemo now and suffer all the effects of chemo now. Would you start chemo when you feel good? Keep on "living with Pca"
Posts.Title: Should I start chemo?

Posts.Content: My oncologist charges 6,000. per injection of Lupron. My urologist charges 2,000. for same injection. They said the difference is the oncologist goes through the hospital and Urologist buys independently. Check around it pays. Carol
Posts.Title: Lupron Depot price shocker

Posts.Content: My oncologist charges 6,000. per injection of Lupron. My urologist charges 2,000. for same injection. They said the difference is the oncologist goes through the hospital and Urologist buys independently. Check around it pays. Carol
Posts.Title: Lupron Depot price shocker

Posts.Content: Steve had his second cycle of chemo and it is working yeaaaaaa psa down from 597 to 208. He has had a few side effects but totally worth getting that cancer to slow down. Has anyone heard of a red face? He looks like he has a red sun burn for about 3 days after chemo. This positive news was just what we need to keep the hope. Even when all is at a very low spot in our life we get something to give us an emotional or spiritual jump. --Carol
Posts.Title: second cycle of taxotere

Posts.Content: Hi I think what you say --says alot. He is 88 with a wife of 81 both are not in good health. Last treatment did not work. He has a lot of cancer. You want the rest of his days to be positive. My husband feels the treatments are sometimes worse than the cancer. Sounds like you have already evaluated the situation and know what is best for you guys. Love each other and enjoy what time you have left. Carol
Posts.Title: My father and Xtandi (enzalutamide) post Zytiga

Posts.Content: Hi chemo can suppresse the bone marrow that makes your blood. It can effects only parts of the blood. Steve had low WBC and has to get Neulasta injections that helps. Than his RBC dropped causing anemia and he got on the ESA apprise oncology program that is injections of Aranesp and it helps. Last time his Platelet counts were low but we reduced the chemo by 20% and that has kept his counts up. It is so hard to keep up with all the side effects and we do not always know if they are caused by chemo or cancer or meds he is getting with chemo or stress or anything else. I am so glad we have a good oncologist and with my research we are able to keep side effects low. I try to stay in front of all side effects so we can react early. So yes low RBC is a side effect of chemo but can be helped. Carol
Posts.Title: Lowered RBCs?

Posts.Content: WOW as I looked at those aggressive fast growing cancer cells on that slide, I would of had a hammer in my hand and "bam bam" you cancer cells. I know I would felt better right there. I will call it the Flintstone therapy. Hope all goes well with you and your choices. Steve
Posts.Title: Another new member of the club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Daughter79 Hello all, My Dad (67) went for a PSA test in 2010 and it came back at over 60 and he was diagnosed with prostate cancer. Following a course of hormone injections and radiotherapy he was given the all clear and put on annual check ups. His PSA remained below 1. He began to feel ill in 2014 and his PSA went up to 9. He had various scans and has been told it's spread 'slightly' to his bones (surrounding area so I'm guessing pelvis?). His last PSA was at 22 and he's on his second hormone injection. Latest PSA result is 25.8 (after one months treatment). Basically - I'm scared about what I've read about Metastatic prostate cancer and don't really understand it. My parents come back from his specialist appointments full of positive news about them being able to control it for 'years' ... but is this true? His results in 2010 were T2 and Gleason of 4+3 - please can someone explain this to me? And will these have changed now it's metastatic? Also - does metastatic mean it's advanced/terminal? I've read so many positive prostate cancer stories ... but it all seems to change once it's spread. Can it spread 'slightly' and be controlled/cured/offer a long life expectancy? Or does the fact it's spread at all ... change things significantly? I'd appreciate any words of wisdom and I apologise in advance if I've not understood the terminology of things or spelt things wrong Many thanks Hi I feel educating your self about prostate cancer is the best. Get on the computor and look up words. Get on you tube and put in advanced prostate cancer there are so many experts who give good opinions. With the advancement in new medications and treatments they can give men years to live, but not everyone response to the treatment the same way so some get less. Go with your parents to appointments sometimes, the oncologist will not mind. Get copies of reports and look up what they mean. Be an advocate for him. Keep records and remind them of appointments. My husbands Psa is 99.5. For five years I have been in the back ground but helping all I can. I hope you get involved and keep "living with Pca" Carol
Posts.Title: First Post: Please help me understand about my Dad - metastatic?

Posts.Title: First Post: Please help me understand about my Dad - metastatic?

Posts.Content: My husband started chemo and is on his 5 th cycle. Upon every appointment there has been a gift from our daughter. She has a bag with treats- lemon drops for bad taste- flavor water- and other treats. Along with a card with encouraging words about strength and fighting this cancer. Our grand daughter adds a color picture to bring him joy. I think all the staff is looking forward to the bags of gifts as much as Steve is. Maybe this can start something from all you caregivers and familys out there It is the things people say and do that heals us as much or more than medical science.
Posts.Title: Daughters gift

Posts.Content: R.T.L My daughter will love the go blue, even though we had some green running thru our family too, our son. It keeps it fun many times. Thanks Carol
Posts.Title: Daughters gift

Posts.Content: Sometimes we just have to have somethings in our control I have read about broccoli, tomatoes, green tea, promegranants, alkaline water, vitamins , suppliments. Some have had a study done. It may or maynot help the cancer but if it makes you feel better/ gives you the fighting attitude even "I can beat this" than you benefited. If you have read or heard about something that helps cancer and you want to try it go for it. Latter on you may say this is a waste of my time and money but today I feel better not eating or eating this. Carol
Posts.Title: Food and Prostate

Posts.Content: Sometimes we just have to have somethings in our control I have read about broccoli, tomatoes, green tea, promegranants, alkaline water, vitamins , suppliments. Some have had a study done. It may or maynot help the cancer but if it makes you feel better/ gives you the fighting attitude even "I can beat this" than you benefited. If you have read or heard about something that helps cancer and you want to try it go for it. Latter on you may say this is a waste of my time and money but today I feel better not eating or eating this. Carol
Posts.Title: Food and Prostate

Posts.Content: Hi Talked with oncologist and he would not give Jevtana every week. He states it has not been approved to give like that and he did not want to try. So Steve got 20 % less dose. He does feel better. The side effects were bad first two cycles and the third cycle the side effects were about half. But He got medications for low WBC / low hgb/ steroids/ IV nausea meds. HIs PSA went from 300 down to 99 on full dose and we get a PSA in two weeks to see if reducing the dose still keeps PSA down. Does he get the Neulasta shot the next day for low wbc? That can causes some pain. Let me know what his PSA was at atart of Jevtana and what it is now please. Steve only got 3 Taxotere doses and PSA went from 597 down to 99 first cycle than back up to 300 by thrid cycle. Thank you Carol
Posts.Title: Chemo dose???

Posts.Content: Steve started Jevtana and two cycles later it is working psa down from 300 to 99 yeaaa. But the side effects are bad. So now the oncologist wants to reduce his Jevtana amount by 20 %. I want to get 50% first week than 50 % second week and none third week. Than he will get 100 % in 21 days but still lower the side effects maybe. Any one out there who got chemo dose different from one cycle every 21 days?? Did your side effects become less?? Carol
Posts.Title: Chemo dose???

Posts.Content: Five years--8 treatments --Stage 4 -advanced pca-psa 322- gleason 9 Working and playing everyday. I am positive all this is because of new research and new discoveries of treatments in the last five years. I know we pay more for treatments in the USA and I want to thank everyone for your part in this, because of you and your paying more we have new ways to help those living with cancer live longer and better. I am one of them. Thanks to all Steve and Carol
Posts.Title: thanks for new treatments

Posts.Content: Hi CinMor I am the wife of Steve in 2009 his psa was 322. GS 9 He has had almost every treatment offered and it has given him more time and a good life. Psa has gone down to 0.3 and back up so many times my graft is to long to see. I hope he has a good oncologist and checks out oxfigo / Xtandi/ Zytiga. They all have proven to slow down spreading of cancer. As our oncologist says I can tell you statistics and what I have seen but every one is different and until you try and get results/ or failures you do not know how long. Steve's psa is at 597 and he had his first chemo last month. Oncologist said I do not think you will ride your harley or work this year if you do not have chemo. but the way I see it Steve will be too sick from chemo to do those things. I pray after chemo is done we get more time that is good. Might not be working or riding but more family time and trips in the car. We take what we are given and are thankful for them. Take care of each other--Carol
Posts.Title: Concerned Prostate Wife

Posts.Content: Hi everyone we have a daughter getting married this year. Steve just got his 3rd dose of chemo and I am not sure if we should make plans for the next few months. Some days he is sick and would not get on a plane but than a week will go by and he works and feel good enough to enjoy a trip. It is so disappointing if he can not attend but even more if I pay and book the trip to have to cancel it all. What do you think? Carol
Posts.Title: Do U make plans??

Posts.Content: So glad you are there to support. I am a spouse and I make sure to talk with Steve. He lets me know when he needs to talk or be alone. He ask me to go with him to appointments and when he thinks he can go alone. But one thing I have noticed when he has an appointment to get results, or some big decision you should go along. Sometimes we handle things great but when we leave and get in the car it is hard to drive home. We break down- cry- get angry- what ever but you being available for strength and encouragement at the right time is most valuable. Carol
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: So glad you are there to support. I am a spouse and I make sure to talk with Steve. He lets me know when he needs to talk or be alone. He ask me to go with him to appointments and when he thinks he can go alone. But one thing I have noticed when he has an appointment to get results, or some big decision you should go along. Sometimes we handle things great but when we leave and get in the car it is hard to drive home. We break down- cry- get angry- what ever but you being available for strength and encouragement at the right time is most valuable. Carol
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Thanks George to be able to switch your mind from negative to positive is something that is learned. As with all education you may fail but repeat-repeat and it will come. Its funny sometimes you get a hug and start to cry and sometimes you get a hug and say I feel better. I am working on spending more time on feeling positive. Steve
Posts.Title: Psychology today weighs in on Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi CinMor I am the wife of Steve in 2009 his psa was 322. GS 9 He has had almost every treatment offered and it has given him more time and a good life. Psa has gone down to 0.3 and back up so many times my graft is to long to see. I hope he has a good oncologist and checks out oxfigo / Xtandi/ Zytiga. I pray after chemo is done we get more time that is good. Might not be working or riding but more family time and trips in the car. We take what we are given and are thankful for them. Posts.Title: Concerned Prostate Wife

Posts.Content: Yes heath care is expensive. Here are some prices we have seen for Prostate care. Zytiga per month 7,000.00 Xgeva injection 7,000.00 per month Oxfigo 30,000.00 per treatment you need 6 treatments Physician charges to give Oxfigo 500.00 per treatment Luperon 2,100.00 per 6 months Started with paying hospital over 6,000.00 per 4 months Provenge over 90,000.00 per treatment took three treatments Radiation was over 300,000.00 for treatments. Thank ful we have great insurance we have a 5,000.00 per year max, and we do have copays for physician appointments all year long.
Posts.Title: Who gives the horomone shot

Posts.Content: My oncologist is connected to the hospital and they charge 6,000 for the same shot the urologist charges 2,000 for. Another oncologist charges 3,000 for the same shot, so check around if you pay or have a copay.
Posts.Title: Who gives the horomone shot

Posts.Content: Yes heath care is expensive. Here are some prices we have seen for Prostate care. Zytiga per month 7,000.00 Xgeva injection 7,000.00 per month Oxfigo 30,000.00 per treatment you need 6 treatments Physician charges to give Oxfigo 500.00 per treatment Luperon 2,100.00 per 6 months Started with paying hospital over 6,000.00 per 4 months Provenge over 90,000.00 per treatment took three treatments Radiation was over 300,000.00 for treatments. Thank ful we have great insurance we have a 5,000.00 per year max, and we do have copays for physician appointments all year long.
Posts.Title: Who gives the horomone shot

Posts.Content: I would like to know how much time chemo brought you? Has it been months since last chemo treatment or maybe years?
Posts.Title: How much time did chemo buy you:

Posts.Content: My oncologist is connected to the hospital and they charge 6,000 for the same shot the urologist charges 2,000 for. Another oncologist charges 3,000 for the same shot, so check around if you pay or have a copay.
Posts.Title: Who gives the horomone shot

Posts.Content: Hi My husband started docetaxel in Jan first cycle no problems when to work every day. Second cycle was nauseated all the time and got so tired about 3 days after chemo that he was to tired to do anything for 5 days. Went back to work feeling tired and took "puke pills" almost every day. Everything tasted bad and he had a hard time eating. Ran high temp. third cycle he was not able to eat or drink and ran temp again. by 5th day after chemo he had to go in for IV fluids and IV antibiotics and IV nausea medications two times. Our dr said chemo starts out not to bad but with every cycle the side effects get more intense. Hope for the best but plan for the worse. He had no problems the day of treatment but I have learned not to make any plans as You never know if he will feel good enought to attend. Feels like week of chemo bad next week getting better third week ok than do it over again. Just keep saying all this is worth it if it is killing the cancer. Take of care of your self too Carol Steves wife
Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!

Posts.Content: Hi Kenny thanks I also have read chemo can give you more time in way of months, but so far I have not heard of anyone getting to much time from the chemo. I had taxotere and first cycle brought Psa down but the next two cycles my psa went up so they say it did not work. Now I am on Cabazitaxel/ Javtana and the first cycle brought psa down and having my psa checked from 2nd cycle in another week. I have met some who got chemo and as long as they were on the chemo psa was down but as soon as the chemo was over in weeks psa came back up. My bone mets is spreading fast so I am hoping for some slowing down of the cancer but that chemo sure is a hard thing to take. Hope someone can share that chemo worked for them by keeping psa down for awhile after treatments were over. Steve
Posts.Title: How much time did chemo buy you:

Posts.Content: PSA came down with Jevtana 300 when started after first Jevtana cycle down to 179 after second cycle found out today it is down to 99. Kenny I have had all the treatments for prostate cancer except no surgery due to turmor was to big. Unless something new comes available soon this is my last treatment. I can still join clinical trials if I find one that will work with me. So I am living for today because this chemo is working. Steve

Posts.Title: .....Chemo time!
